title: "Happy, smiley" girl, 20, bravely shares psychotic visions of people screaming that can be triggered by a single comment
text:
News "Happy, smiley" girl, 20, bravely shares psychotic visions of people screaming that can be triggered by a single comment Student Sophie Eliza suffers from horrific episodes that can be set off by something as small saying a comment she disagrees with, causing her to see things that aren't real Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Reality of living with psychosis revealed by "happy" student Share this video Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
The happy, smiley photo of Sophie Eliza with her boyfriend Alex depicts the person everyone knows her as. 
But the brave 20-year-old has released footage of her during a psychotic episode - which she describes as her "break from reality" - to show what it's like living with a mental illness. 
The Classics student wants to challenge the stigma and get people talking about mental health , and insists living with psychosis and "seeing things happening that aren't" doesn't mean she isn't happy at the same time. 
"Both parts are real, they are both me. Being happy and being depressed are not mutually exclusive," Sophie, from Birmingham said. Sophie suffers with psychosis but says she is still happy (Photo: Facebook) Sophie during an episode (Photo: Facebook) 
The video shows Sophie during a psychotic episode, seeing visions of people screaming, covered in blood - but Sophie says when she started filming she had "calmed down a bit," had taken her emergency drugs and had previously been much worse. 
In an interview with Mirror Online, she explained her trigger before these visions last week was watching a TV programme featuring a man who suffers with paranoid schizophrenia. 
This set her off, and her mind was filled with visions of people screaming. Read More Sophie's psychosis makes her feel tired (Photo: Facebook) Sophie post seizure after I had got a piece of glass in her face (Photo: Facebook) 
Describing what goes on in her head, she said: "I have to try and recognise what's real and what isn't. I ask myself if there are really people in my house or if the voices I hear are real. 
"My visions are both reality and fiction at the same time. 
"In the video I have already taken my emergency medication, so I wasn't as bad as I had been- which is scary." 
In an honest Facebook post she wrote: "This is the reality of psychotic illnesses. This is the reality for some with bipolar, or bpd, severe depression or schizophrenia (all of which I've been diagnosed with at some point). 
"Mental illnesses aren't romantic or beautiful or cute. Mental illnesses are scary, terrifying. Mental illnesses aren't a personality trait. Mental illnesses aren't a quirk. And I am not too happy to have one (or several). 
"Mental illnesses are serious, they're dangerous and ugly. This is the reality of being triggered by something. Being triggered by something can lead to this. This state of pure agony and fear. 
"Sometimes it involves voices but at a level I can deal with. But sometimes, it's far more aggressive. Sometimes, it makes me believe things that aren't real. 
"It makes me see things that aren't real. It makes me feel things that aren't real, including physical pain. It makes me relive the worst moments of my life again and again with no escape. But those traumas are mine and I keep them with me at all times, wherever I go." Sophie has bravely spoken out about her mental health (Photo: Facebook) Sophie insists she is a smiley, happy person generally (Photo: Facebook) Sophie and her dog (Photo: Facebook) 
Sophie explained how tiny her triggers can be. 
Just a few weeks ago somebody said something really small that she disagreed with, but she began obsessing over it for three or four days. 
"I was crying and shaking. That's not normal behaviour," she said. "It can be something really little that triggers an episode and my vision of reality just changes so quickly." 
Despite all of this, Sophie insists she's a happy person generally. 
She lives with her boyfriend Alex, who she says is an incredible support and really understands that she can be "ill and not ill at the same time". 
She said being happy can be tiring though, and if she has a good day, she can spend the following day in bed. Sophie and her boyfriend Alex who is a huge support to her (Photo: Facebook) 
Her episodes build up over time, and it takes a while reach the stage she's at in the video. 
The signs normally start with Sophie feeling tired, taking naps during the day, enjoying things less, feeling reluctant to go outside, not caring about her appearance as much, and not wanting to see her friends. 
Sophie's psychotic episodes started in January 2016, as it was the anniversary of three personal traumas that had happened in her life. 
She was then officially diagnosed with psychosis and prescribed anti-psychotic medication that April, and now she takes medication in the morning and at night. 
Sophie had already been diagnosed with depression and anxiety in 2012. 
She has taught herself self help techniques to deal with her depression using www.blurtitout.org. Like us on Facebook
